learning_outcomes.description: Professional Standard 1.3 Demonstrate knowledge of teaching strategies that are responsive to the learning strengths and needs of students from diverse linguistic, cultural, religious and socioeconomic backgrounds.
Professional Standard 1.5 Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of strategies for differentiating teaching to meet the specific learning needs of students across the full range of abilities.
Professional Standard 2.1 Demonstrate knowledge and understanding of the concepts, substance and structure of the content and teaching strategies of the teaching area.
Professional Standard 2.5 Know and understand literacy and numeracy teaching strategies and their application in teaching areas.
Professional Standard 2.6 Implement teaching strategies for using ICT to expand curriculum learning opportunities for students.
Professional Standard 3.3 Include a range of teaching strategies.
Professional Standard 3.4 Demonstrate knowledge of a range of resources, including ICT, that engage students in their learning.
Professional Standard 3.5 Demonstrate a range of verbal and non-verbal communication strategies to support student engagement.
Professional Standard 3.6 Demonstrate broad knowledge of strategies that can be used to evaluate teaching programs to improve student learning.
Professional Standard 4.2 Demonstrate the capacity to organise classroom activities and provide clear directions.
Professional Standard 5.2 Demonstrate an understanding of the purpose of providing timely and appropriate feedback to students about their learning.
Professional Standard 5.3 Demonstrate understanding of assessment moderation and its application to support consistent and comparable judgements of student learning.
Professional Standard 5.4 Demonstrate the capacity to interpret student assessment data to evaluate student learning and modify teaching practice.
Professional Standard 6.3 Seek and apply constructive feedback from supervisors and teachers to improve teaching practices.
Demonstrate the ability to effectively collaborate with others to complete group tasks.

assessments.task_description:
Quizzes will be a mixture of multiple-choice and short answer questions.

  • Quiz 1: Teaching Literacy - Knowledge of effective teaching of literacy.
  • Quiz 2: Teaching Numeracy - Knowledge of effective teaching of numeracy.
  • Quiz 3: Quality Teaching of Literacy and Numeracy - Knowledge of the MTSS framework, providing effective feedback and re-teaching concepts with scaffolding.

Use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be completed in-person as a paper-based quiz.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
You will engage in a cycle of planning-teaching-reflecting by teaching two sequenced lessons in class (see Learning Activities for dates). You will be assessed on your written reflection of your planning and teaching.

Use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be submitted via the relevant Turnitin submission portal on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
With a literacy and numeracy focus, review school students' class work and assessment task to provide quality feedback and create differentiated learning tasks. You'll be using actual Year 8/9 student work and NAPLAN data to undertake this task.

Use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be submitted via the relevant Turnitin submission portal on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Teaching Literacy and Numeracy for HPE & Science: An Introduction

In this session, you will be introduced to the power and importance of literacy and numeracy in your teaching. We will tap into contemporary research and curriculum to know that:

  • Explicit instruction in reading and writing literacy is foundational to academic success, and that discipline-specific literacy instruction enhances students' comprehension, metacognition and engagement.
  • Numeracy is a foundational to interpret and critique data, evaluate evidence, and engage in informed discussions. This supports critical thinking and reasoning to understand public information, such as statistics in media, and to make informed decisions.

Additionally, you will start your Peer Teaching assessment.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L08
learning_activities.topic_title: Teaching Literacy and Numeracy for HPE & Science: An Introduction

We will tap into contemporary research and curriculum to know that: Explicit instruction in reading and writing literacy is foundational to academic success, and that discipline-specific literacy instruction enhances students' comprehension, metacognition and engagement. Numeracy is a foundational to interpret and critique data, evaluate evidence, and engage in informed discussions. This supports critical thinking and reasoning to understand public information, such as statistics in media, and to make informed decisions. Additionally, you will start your Peer Teaching assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
Peer Teaching 1

You will present your first Peer Teaching lesson during this class (assessment task). You will collect feedback and learning data to use as evidence in your written assessment task.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L08, L09, L10, L14

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 4 To Week 5(16 Mar - 29 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Literacy: Teaching Writing, Reading & Viewing, and Speaking & Listening (3 weeks; continued)

In this series, you will explore explicit teaching strategies and tools for teaching general and discipline-specific literacy to school students.

This includes an understanding of:

  • How the brain learns to read and write
  • Bloom’s taxonomy and cognitive verbs
  • Phonemic awareness, phonics and reading with fluency
  • Effective teaching of vocabulary, comprehension and oral language
  • How to use graphic organisers for scaffolding, comprehension and writing
  • Employing writing-to-learn strategies including note-taking and summarizing
  • Teach genre writing strategies for persuasive texts, reflections and research reports
  • Spotting and re-teaching literacy errors and misconceptions

All sessions will embed ideas for constructing engaging lessons including classroom organisation, communication strategies and the use of ICTs for learning.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L10
learning_activities.topic_title: Literacy: Teaching Writing, Reading & Viewing, and Speaking & Listening (3 weeks; continued)
learning_activities.topic_description: Literacy: Teaching Writing, Reading & Viewing, and Speaking & Listening (3 weeks; continued) In this series, you will explore explicit teaching strategies and tools for teaching general and discipline-specific literacy to school students. This includes an understanding of: How the brain learns to read and write Bloom’s taxonomy and cognitive verbs Phonemic awareness, phonics and reading with fluency Effective teaching of vocabulary, comprehension and oral language How to use graphic organisers for scaffolding, comprehension and writing Employing writing-to-learn strategies including note-taking and summarizing Teach genre writing strategies for persuasive texts, reflections and research reports Spotting and re-teaching literacy errors and misconceptions All sessions will embed ideas for constructing engaging lessons including classroom organisation, communication strategies and the use of ICTs for learning.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 6 To Week 7(30 Mar - 19 Apr)
learning_activities.topic:
Numeracy: Number Sense & Algebra, Statistics & Probability and Measurement & Geometry (3 weeks total)

In this series, you will explore explicit teaching strategies and tools for teaching general and discipline-specific numeracy to school students.

This includes an understanding of:

  • Underpinning mathematical concepts and skills (numerical, spatial, graphical, statistical, and algebraic), and mathematical thinking and strategies
  • Conceptual understanding of numeracy proficiencies (understanding, fluency, problem solving and reasoning)
  • Graphing for HPE and Science
  • How to use graphic organisers for numeracy
  • Meta-cognitive strategies for problem solving and reasoning
  • Spotting and re-teaching mathematical misconceptions and misunderstandings 

All sessions will embed ideas for constructing engaging lessons including classroom organisation, communication strategies and the use of ICTs for learning.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05, L06, L07, L10
learning_activities.topic_title: Numeracy: Number Sense & Algebra, Statistics & Probability and Measurement & Geometry (3 weeks total)

Learning outcomes: L05, L10, L14

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 10 To Week 13(04 May - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Feedback for Learning (3 weeks total)

In this series, you will learn how to provide effective feedback to students, and evaluate teaching programs using research-informed approaches to improve student learning.

This includes an understanding of:

  • Hattie’s meta-analysis and feedback questions (Where am I going? How am I going? Where to next?) 
  • How to provide feedback that is specific, honest, constructive, clear and supportive to students – why, what, when, who and how. 
  • The theoretical underpinnings of the Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) framework and how it works in the classroom.
  • Marking and moderation practices used by teachers

All sessions will embed ideas for constructing engaging lessons including classroom organisation, communication strategies and the use of ICTs for learning.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L09, L11, L12, L13
learning_activities.topic_description: Feedback for Learning (3 weeks total) In this series, you will learn how to provide effective feedback to students, and evaluate teaching programs using research-informed approaches to improve student learning. This includes an understanding of: Hattie’s meta-analysis and feedback questions (Where am I going? How am I going? Where to next?) How to provide feedback that is specific, honest, constructive, clear and supportive to students – why, what, when, who and how. The theoretical underpinnings of the Multi-Tiered System of Supports (MTSS) framework and how it works in the classroom. Marking and moderation practices used by teachers All sessions will embed ideas for constructing engaging lessons including classroom organisation, communication strategies and the use of ICTs for learning.
